channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Shake Up Corporate Japan
item.description: A crosshatch of stock holdings allows Japan’s big corporations to protect one another from outside attempts to shake up management. The prime minister has taken aim at the practice.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Mr. Abe, Japan’s prime minister, has proposed untangling the protective mutual stockholdings among corporations.

item.title: Long Absent, Nuclear Expert Still Has Hold on Iran Talks
item.description: Without Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, who is believed to be leading Iran’s nuclear program, an agreement on negotiations will lack real understanding of how close Iran is to building a nuclear warhead.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Doubting Putin, Obama Prepares to Add Pressure
item.description: The Obama administration has drawn up plans to escalate sanctions against Russia by targeting its financial, energy and defense industries.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:description: A mechanic cleared debris Tuesday after overnight shelling at a coal mine in the Luhansk region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: After Opening Way to Rebels, Turkey Is Paying Heavy Price
item.description: Many Turks now blame their government for facilitating the rise of extremists in Syria and the new insurgency in Iraq, including the kidnapping of 80 Turkish citizens.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two sons and two nephews of Mehmet Selim Karakan, center, were kidnapped by ISIS while trucking goods to Iraq from Turkey.

item.title: Kerry Implores Kurdish Leader to Join a Government and Not Break Away
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry urged the president of Iraq’s Kurdish autonomous region not to seek his own state and instead help form a government in Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Masoud Barzani, the president of Iraq’s Kurdish autonomous region, on Tuesday in Erbil, Iraq.

item.title: World Briefing : Mexico: Cartel Leader Is Arrested
item.description: The head of the once-mighty Arellano Felix drug cartel, based in Tijuana, was arrested while watching Mexico’s soccer team play in the World Cup, Monte Alejandro Rubido, the federal police chief, said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Lawmakers’ Vote Advances Ban of Birth Control Procedures
item.description: Iran moved toward criminalizing vasectomies and tubal ligations on Tuesday as lawmakers approved a bill meant to counter a drop in the country’s population, the semi-official Iranian Students’ News Agency reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Deadly Attack on Plane
item.description: Gunmen fired on a plane as it was landing in the northern city of Peshawar on Tuesday night, striking a Pakistani passenger in the head in front of her young daughter and injuring three crew members.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Court Rules on End-of-Life Case
item.description: France’s highest administrative court, the Conseil d’État, ruled Tuesday that a feeding tube could legally be removed from a 38-year-old man in a persistent vegetative state, whose care has been part of a long, bitter public fight involving the country’s end-of-life legislation.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Harvard Scholar’s Body Cremated After Request for Burial in Iran Falters
item.description: A Harvard scholar who wanted to be buried in Iran, a request that angered hard-liners there, has been cremated by his family in Boston, the Iranian news media reported Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Questions Rebels Use to Tell Sunni From Shiite
item.description: How can the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria tell whether a person is a Sunni or a Shiite? From accounts, it seems they often ask a list of questions.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Death Penalty Overturned for Wife Who Killed Abuser
item.description: In a case greeted as a breakthrough for women’s rights, the Chinese Supreme Court has overturned a death sentence issued to a woman who killed her husband after years of abuse, and ordered a retrial.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Li Yan, whose case will be retried.

item.title: Errant Rocket in Gaza Is Said to Kill Girl, 3
item.description: The Israeli military said the airstrikes that followed were in response to the militants’ firing of five rockets from Gaza.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Breaking the Law to Go Online in Iran
item.description: Top officials enjoy what they deny to their citizens: social media.
item.dc:creator: By SETAREH DERAKHSHESH

item.title: Dortmund Journal: A Neo-Nazi’s Political Rise Exposes a German City’s Ethnic Tensions
item.description: In Dortmund, divisions are growing not just between native Germans and more recent arrivals, but also among the city’s many immigrant groups.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Siegfried Borchardt won a seat on Dortmund’s City Council pushing an anti-immigration “Germany for Germans” agenda.

item.title: Mother Seeks U.N.’s Help to Return Israeli Youths
item.description: In an emotional address, Rachel Fraenkel, the mother of Naftali Fraenkel, 16, said, “I believe much more could be done and should be done by so many.”
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Rachel Fraenkel, center, mother of one of three missing Jewish teenagers, spoke during a broadcast last week, along with her husband and the parents of the other two youths.

item.title: Uruguay’s Suárez, Known for Biting, Leaves Mark on World Cup
item.description: For the third time in the past four years, Uruguay’s star striker, Luis Suárez, appeared to bite a player on the other team when he clashed with Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini in the second half.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Italy's Giorgio Chiellini claimed that he was bitten on the shoulder by Uruguay's Luis Suárez.

item.title: Asiana Employees’ Training Was Deficient, N.T.S.B. Says
item.description: The Asiana pilots hit the sea wall just short of the runway in San Francisco because they did not understand crucial details of the cockpit automation, the National Transportation Safety Board said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: A National Transportation Safety Board hearing in Washington on Tuesday. The board found the crew of the Boeing 777 apparently relied on aspects of the plane's automatic systems which they did not fully understand.

item.title: Ex-Tabloid Executive Acquitted in British Phone Hacking Case
item.description: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s newspaper holdings in Britain, was cleared of all charges, but her onetime deputy Andy Coulson was found guilty on at least one count.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Andy Coulson, a former tabloid editor and onetime head of communications for Prime Minister David Cameron, was the only person among the seven found guilty of conspiracy to intercept mobile phone calls and messages.

item.title: German Publishers Seek Amazon Inquiry
item.description: A German publishers group asked officials to investigate Amazon’s dealings with Bonnier Media during a dispute over e-book sales.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Amazon’s Augsburg, Germany, center. The company is accused of delaying some shipments.

item.title: Putin Presses Extension of Cease-Fire in Ukraine
item.description: In another move seen as a step toward ending the conflict, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia also asked lawmakers to rescind a resolution authorizing the use of force in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin on an official visit in Vienna on Tuesday.

item.title: 1 Killed and 20 Hurt in Overnight Bombing in Lebanon
item.description: A suicide bombing in a southern Beirut neighborhood killed a security officer and wounded 20 people, officials said Tuesday, as an al-Qaida-linked group warned that such attacks will continue as long as the militant Hezbollah group is taking part in Syria’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Soldiers and investigators worked Tuesday at the site of a suicide car bombing in a Beirut suburb. The Monday night explosion killed a security officer and wounded several people in a cafe.

item.title: Sudan Said to Revive Notorious Militias
item.description: The government’s new Rapid Support Forces are a version of the janjaweed militias that terrorized people in Darfur, and have been attacking villages again, a rights group said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 24
item.description: Female police personnel marching during a parade in Gandhinagar, Gujarat.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Female police officers during a passing out parade at the Gujarat Police Academy in Gandhinagar.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Michael Tien on Why He Thinks Occupy Central Is a Mistake
item.description: Michael Tien, a leader of the pro-establishment New People’s Party, says democrats could forfeit an opportunity to achieve a more accountable government.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A volunteer for the Occupy Central movement passing by voters outside a polling station during an unofficial referendum on electoral reforms in Hong Kong.
